Iliya Agoshkov wrote:
> But this (testing private methods) helps in quickly localizing the source of the problem. Doesn’t it?
> 

Only if you guess right about where the problem is. I can accept a quick 
test of a private method as exploratory coding and a convenience, 
provided that before fixing the alleged bug you verify it with a test of 
the same thing that goes through the public API, and that you remove the 
private test after debugging and before final shipment.

However, the experience of figuring out exactly how the private method 
is invoked often reveals more about the code than merely looking at the 
private method through a peephole. Sometimes the bug turns out not to be 
what I thought it was. Sometimes I discover that the bug in fact cannot 
occur through the public API. This enables me to take shortcuts and make 
optimizations in private methods that I could not do in public methods. 
Often the sheer process of thinking in depth about the  execution path 
into the private method reveals aspects of the code I did not previously 
understand and shows me how to improve and refactor the code so 
radically that the problem vanishes completely.
